testimony: Morning everybody.  We'll continue with the CCB hearing.  Has it been decided who the next applicant's going to be Mr du Plessis.
Yes, Mr Chairman, he's ready to give evidence.
EXAMINATION BY MR P DU PLESSIS
Mr Maree you are an applicant in this matter for amnesty in terms of the National Unity and Reconciliation Act 34 of 95 in regard to an incident regarding Gavin Evans, is that correct?
And your application was filed on the 2nd of December 1996.  It's dated the 2nd of November 96, is that correct?
Now also as far as you're concerned, you initially applied in terms of the first Act, number 35 of 1990, the "Wet of Vrywaring", is that correct?
Sorry, yes while we're busy, do you prefer speaking English or Afrikaans?
Mr Chairman, can I just sort this out with the applicant.
Mr Maree, it's your choice, whatever language you want to speak, please feel free to do so.
Very well, I will give evidence in Afrikaans and English with cross-examination.
Speak to Mr du Plessis, maybe he has ...
Thank you Mr Chairman, it's sorted out, he will give his evidence-in-chief in Afrikaans and he will answer the cross-examination in English, where applicable, from Mr Kahanovitz.
We won't hold you to that Mr Maree.  If you want to at any stage speak Afrikaans or English, that's up to you.
Very well Mr Maree let us then  speak Afrikaans at this stage.  So you made that initial application in terms of the Act that is dated the 28th March?
Concerning that application, there was no formal reply to it.

But later you did receive notice that in terms of the Act, in terms of further indemnity, that this first application of yours was referred to the hearing of two Judges in Bloemfontein and indeed it was done on the 9th of December 1993, where you were then represented by Attorney Havenga and Juri Wessels and they argued on behalf of you.  Were you present there?

Well, also concerning this, there was no feedback in terms of the publication of the indemnity in the Government Gazette and then the next step was that in terms of the Act of 34/95, you apply for amnesty?
And this is now in terms of the incident around Gavin Evans?
Now this application of yours, it's now this application that is serving in front of the Commission at this stage?
And you were then assisted by Adv Swiegelaar and you application is in the form of, or with your annexures dated 28th of March 1991, is that correct?

We will come back to this at a later stage.  Very well, before we then deal with the matter as such, I think it is necessary for us to allow you to continue and explain to us in your own words, what the background was.  The first issue that I'd like to deal with is your own personal background.  I assume you are a South African citizen and that you grew up in Natal?
Mr du Plessis, you heard that?
I seem to be the culprit.
That is correct.  I grew up and schooled in Port Shepstone.  I then joined the police in 1971 and I finished school in 1970.
If you could just slow down for the interpreter.
I apologise.  Directly after school I joined the Police Force and I went to the Police College in Pretoria.
We are now talking about 1970, is that correct?
From there, after the Police College, I went to Pietermaritzburg, from there to Empangeni and from Empangeni Detective Branch to the Brixton Murder and Robbery Unit.
What year would this be where you joined the Brixton Murder and Robbery Unit?
You were then attached to the Brixton Murder and Robbery Unit up until 1988, is that correct?
What was your rank when you started your service?
I would just like to deal with the circumstances around the fact that you then left the Police Service.  Can you just in short explain this to us?

I investigated a murder case or a few murders where the suspects that I identified were Mr le Grange, a former Captain of Murder and Robbery and Robert van der Merwe who was also at the Brixton Murder and Robbery Unit.
It was the murder of drug smugglers.
Yes.  I made my presentation to the Commander.
This is now Staal Burger who is also an applicant in this matter?
Yes. Because Capt le Grange was an officer,  the dossier was taken from me and then handed over to Pretoria for further investigations.
This Capt le Grange as you've already mentioned, was then an officer at the Brixton Murder and Robbery.
He was a former Captain at Brixton, but he was then part of the East Rand at that stage.
But if you say Brixton Murder and Robbery, you say that you knew him?
And that is the reason why the file was taken from you?
What - this whole matter round le Grange, what led to it?
Well, there was certain communication between the Attorney-General's office and certain members at Brixton and also at Head Office, they were asked to transfer certain people and I was amongst them.
I was transferred to the Durban Murder and Robbery Unit.
So once again, it was a Murder and Robbery branch.  Was this seen as a reflection on your capacity and your impartiality?
Yes.  I believed it was not because I did anything wrong in the investigation.
Did you then indeed accept that transfer to Durban?
Yes, initially I did when I was called to Pretoria, but in the interim stage I was then approached by Col Burger.
Well, this now includes the recruitment for the CCB.  If you can just continue and tell us what happened then.
Col Burger then approached me and asked me if I was interested in joining the Special Forces, Special Forces asked him to do certain recruitments.
It was then known as the "recce"?
That is correct.  At that stage I was interested in looking at, or to accept the recruitment, I then attended a meeting where Sterk addressed us.
Were there other members who were then later recruited?  Who were they?
Was this meeting at a military compound?
No, it was on the Ponti Building in Hillbrow.
Did you say who was present as well?
It was Calla Botha, Staal Burger and Mr van Zyl.
Did you then accept the appointment?
Yes, after I spoke to Mr Verster and he explained to me what this entailed, I considered it and I think two days later I came back to Mr Burger and told him that I accepted.
You then resigned from the South African Police Service?
Just in short, the initial description of the unit, the Special Forces Unit of the Defence Force, what did this entail?

What they told me was that it was a covert arm of Special Forces and at that stage I did not have a lot of knowledge concerning Special Forces, so I accepted, as they explained it, covert in the line of the Security Branch of the Police.
Mr Chairman, there seems to be a problem with Mr Kahanovitz, I don't know whether it's about...
It's just to do with the quality of the sound in Afrikaans and it seems to have to do with the position of the microphones and also the speed at which they're speaking.

Thank you Mr Chairman.  Very well, you are now talking about the covert operations.  So you were under the impression, or you were brought under the impression from the start, that you will not run around in Angola in uniform.  What was your impression then?  Where will you be stationed and what would the circumstances be under which you would work?

Initially they told us, because there was a contract or an agreement between the South African Police and the South African Defence Force, there will be a cooling off period of 6 months, thereafter we will get an office in Johannesburg and that did occur.
In other words you'll be stationed in Johannesburg?
And on that basis you then accepted it?

At that stage of your recruitment, was there any discussion or talk that you would have to act in any illegal way and that would fall in the parameters of your services as the Special Forces of the Defence Force?
You then mentioned that they told you that there would be a cooling off period of six months.  But just before we get to that, did you receive an official service contract?
Yes, I signed it and handed it over to Mr Verster.
Now what was your impression?  For what institute or organisation were you working for?
The name CCB, was that known to you, that it would be a branch of the Defence Force?
No, not with the first meeting.
So when you signed the contract, the name was then made known to you?
This contract I think was, if I can recall correctly, with the organisation and it said CCB, but the word used was organisations.
It has been put to you before that the CCB stood separate from the Defence Force in the sense that the activities of the CCB could not lead back to the Defence Force, do you understand what I mean?
This is also how you were informed?
Yes, that's how I understood it.
But did you understand that you will not be in the service of the Defence Force then?
No, that it would be a covert organisation.
And your Commander of this specific unit?
Gen Joubert, did you meet him?
So in other words, it was a General that was in full-time employment of the Defence Force?
So you had no doubt that you were working for a State Organisation and for the Security Forces at that stage?
No, I had no illusion that I worked for the Defence Force, that is correct.
And that's also where you money came from, the salaries and the funding for certain projects?

During this cooling-off period, we've also heard other evidence and I do not think it is disputed that there was no activation and you did not really serve in the traditional sense of the word, during that period of 6 months, up until December 1988?
But you did have contact with the organisation, is that correct?
Who was know to you as Christo Brits.  Was he ...?
He was the co-ordinator of Region 6.
And this contact during that 6 month period, where did this happen, or how did it happen?
It was mostly meetings at different hotels in hotel rooms.
In short, it was at the start of it, we tried to sort out the documentation.  We had no documentation so we tried to find all of that out.
Then it's also common cause that you were later activated in January 1989.
And that indeed the course was presented and that you went through this course and amongst others, Joe Verster, Wouter Basson and others addressed you?
Am I also correct that it was also the Commanding General, who was Joubert at that stage?
Now without dealing with this extensively, what did this course entail?

There were different phases.  Once again the military style of administration.  Because we were Special Forces we did things differently.  We did the writing of documents, the purpose of the organisation was explained to us.
Being the disruption of the enemy of the country.
Was the enemy explained to you or spelled out?
Yes, at that stage, I think it was common knowledge that it was the ANC, the PAC or the so-called freedom fighters, which we called the terrorists and today are called the freedom fighters.
Well, what was put to you in broad terms concerning your functions?

What was put to us, in broader terms was that the day of conventional warfare in South Africa is over, the enemy is now in the country and that we are a similar organisation and we will fight fire with fire and we will adapt our methods to theirs.
It was the elimination of people, the burning of houses or any disruption to ...
Would this include fund organisations of the ANC, to act against the ANC?
At that stage you just left the South African Police, what was your perception concerning those circumstances in the country?

Well from the police's side I was aware of it.  I was aware that there were bombs in the country, that bombs were planted against the State, friends of mine, policemen who were blown up, cars that were blown up, so I was aware that the war was in the country, I was aware of this.
And did you sympathise with the tasks of the South African Defence Force?
Yes, I did, I was part of them.
Very well, we will at a later stage deal with that area, but was it explained to you how these covert operations would work?
Yes, in broader terms they explained to us that the blue plan and a red plan ...
That would be then the cover, to give you access?
And also to give you a legitimate base to work from, from there you would then execute your operations?
And the red plan would then be the activation in terms of the operations against the enemy?
And with that you confirm what has already been said in terms of the recruitment of unconscious agents?
I'm not going to cover all of that again, but you then indeed after you completed that course, took certain steps to establish a cover for yourself?
What did you then do in terms of the establishment of a blue plan cover?
Well, I established a front company for the export from South Africa to other African countries, electronic appliances, computers, pocket calculators, watches, etc.
You now said that you established a company, was this a formal company?
It was Lema, L-E-M-A, was the name of the company.
Well, it is the first two letters of my name and then my surname.  The company I established in Johannesburg, funding was approved for the establishment of this company by the Defence Force.
Was this then an official request for funds that you had to do through documentation?
Can you recall what type of funds were made available to you?
At a certain stage, R40 000 was made available for the company.
What would you use it for?
Well it would be the buying of furniture to furnish the offices.
That is correct yes, for the first month or two.
And did you then use those funds?
Yes, I did, some of it, but my plans changed, I did not buy furniture but I started renting furnished offices.
Was this now in a centre where there were offices and also furniture and also personnel?
They were in Park Town in Johannesburg and I then gave back the rest of the money until I needed it at a later stage.
So if I understand you correctly, you made a monthly withdrawal and rather than using the whole lump sum at the same time.
When you activated this company, was it a business?

Yes, it was a business.  I did business and I also embarked on a - because it was a new area, I'm a policeman, I do not know anything about business and I thought if I had people around me who knew about it, I could learn from them, that's why I started with a very small company.  I then did that and after a few months I started with these things that I exported.  I started making money and then I got a partner to assist me in it.
So you then indeed, to put it this way, you had a bona fide business?
Was the idea of this whole system that you would have a believable cover or was it only a door where there's nothing going on behind it?

I understood and later I went into it a bit further, that it was very important to have a good foundation, a very good blue plan.  To get access you need, if somebody asks you, you must seem legitimate.  If somebody comes to your office, it must seem as if there's things going on and I tried to do this to the best of my abilities.

So it is a question where in the community you want to establish yourself as a businessman, it's not just a front door, you must indeed run a business and people must trust you doing it and you then did it?

At the, or during this initial term from January to March, we also heard evidence that there were basically provinces given to the different members of Region 6 on the ground floor level, that was yourself and Mr Botha and you had to concentrate on these areas?
But you were not always applied in these areas?
And that KwaZulu Natal was given to you so that you could also establish yourself there and that would be the province on which you would focus?
Why was this done?  Is there any specific reason for this?
Well, because I went to school there and I grew up there and I knew Natal and I assume that was the reason.
But out of your evidence before, it seemed that if you were to ...(indistinct) as a detective or policeman and you did not work in Natal.
It's true, I knew the area but I've lost contact with a lot of the people there, but I went back to look up old friends and to make contact with them again.
Very well.  Did you also extend your business activities?
Yes, I also established a company in Durban that provided goods to ships coming in and once again I got a partner to run the business to give me the freedom to move around.
He did not know what was going on?
He was completely unconscious, he did not know what was going on.
And was this once again a normal branch or office?
It was not the same type of work as the first company. I provided goods to ships that came into the harbour.
Can you still recall the name of the company?
Was it once again a formal company?
You say that this company did indeed run the business and did do business.  Did you make use of the funds?
No, the Lema office in Johannesburg, I just took one or two months of their profit to make use, to buy furniture.
So you were running the Lema business at a profit?

And you used that money to create the company in Natal.  If I understand you correctly, it was not against the rules of the CCB, it was indeed the policy of the CCB that you will have a legitimate business, you will establish this business from which you can then draw a salary or that you can make a living with it and you were supported in this, that you were going to make a profit in it and make use of it?
That is correct.  I did run it in terms of the profit, but it was not the purpose to get a salary from it, but I got a salary from the Defence Force.
It wasn't a factor however, this is now from the profits of the company?
But you had to make a profit otherwise the company would not exist.
Just to come back to what you have already said to us.  You spoke to us about CAPALL, the other company that did business, to come back to Lema, this company you say did exports to what country?
Well, it was Zambia, Swaziland, Botswana, African countries around us.
Very well.  Did you personally, in order to further your exports, did you travel to these countries?
What was the purpose of it?

To receive business or to get business from those countries.   Because I didn't have people on the grassroots level, I don't have experience, so I wen to the Chambers of Commerce in these countries and they referred me to companies, gave me names and contracts with companies I can do business with, so I can then choose whom I want to deal with.

And this was in the furthering of your business in terms of the blue plan?  You had no illusions that you would then, or the fact that you could move freely in those countries, that it can be an advantage for the CCB?
That is correct, that was the purpose thereof.
When you say it was the purpose thereof, when you were to focus on Natal, ...
To give me freedom of movement, Sir.
Yes, but I mean your function in the CCB wasn't it to focus on KwaZulu Natal?
So in what way would it be beneficial to the CCB if you could wander around freely in Namibia or Zambia or Swaziland or Botswana?
Not necessarily to do that.  On the course we were told that we must access freedom of movement wherever we want to and that's what I tried to do there.

Thank you Mr Chairman.  And then perhaps just to clarify the point which was touched upon by the Chairperson a few moments ago, if I understand you correctly, these activities of yours, the establishment of Lema, the exports, the movements in the African countries, all of this took place in January, February, March, April of 1989, the initial months?
Yes, the first few months of 1989.
Now as a result of this successful establishment of Lema and the exports particularly, was there any movement in the CCB as a result of this, especially with regard to its functions?
There was another company which I established, yes.  I also established Lema in Windhoek, in Namibia.
Was it a branch of Lema?
Yes, it was a company on it's own, it was Lema, Namibia.
Was it also an incorporated company?
And regarding these activities of yours, was there ever any change with regard to the CCB's plans with you?
Yes.  Later I was called in by Mr Burger and I was asked whether I would be interested in working in Germany.

And then with regard to Africa, can you give us an indication of when the Germany offer came about?
If we could just establish the course of time.  We've examined January to April, that was the African situation and then emanating there from, did you follow any courses or anything like that?
Out of my own, I followed a business management course because I was a layman, I didn't really know much and I needed to learn more.
At Executive Education.  It was a very basic Management course.
Who paid for the course?  The CCB actually?
And this question that you would focus abroad and ultimately in Germany, was this your own initiative or was it from the CCB?
And was this based upon your successful activities in other African Countries, as you have just explained to us?
I think it was based upon my blue companies which had been successfully established that they functioned efficiently.
Was your function then at that point when you were asked to focus or concentrate on foreign countries, was your focus still specifically on KwaZulu Natal in the sense that it was your job?
I was told to work in Natal, but I viewed this over the long term and I thought that I should first establish a sound basis.
Yes, it gave me the freedom to move to Durban because I had to work in Natal.  I had a reason to go to Durban without any questions being asked.

Now the establishment of blue plans and the establishment of a credible front for the CCB, was this a sort of crises management which was executed over the short term, or was it a long term plan?  What was your perception?

It was my perception that it was a long term plan, that it had to be done proficiently.  That is what I tried to do.  I tried to establish a sound basis.  I viewed it in the long term and I was also told that it was a long term thing.
So you were told so?  Why were you told so?
I was told so by Mr Burger, Mr Verster and during the course.
Was any pressure exerted on you to deliver so-called production with regard to the projects and execution of such projects?
No, it was said that this was a significant phase, the establishment of an efficient blue plan.

You see, because questions have been put here, among others, by the Chairperson that it seems somewhat difficult to understand that the person Chappies Maree, as he is known, is in disfavour with Mr Slang van Zyl with regard to production.  It would appear that you were there for nine months, and with the exception of Gavin Evans, nothing happened.

Yes, it must be so, we had different working methods.  My blue plan entrapped me in the sense that I found myself in a situation for a number of months where I didn't know anything about business, but I had to deal with businesses and staff members and I was caught up in the whole idea of running a business, rather than delivering production.
Later we will deal in specific terms with Gavin Evans, but it is common cause that in approximately March 1989, an instruction came your way with regard to Gavin Evans?
And that you indeed executed your instruction with regard to that.  It is not common cause as such perhaps, but you could perhaps inform us regarding this.  What was your precise instruction?

I was given a document, or at least a document was shown to me by Mr Basson and I was given an instruction to trace Gavin Evans' address and his place of employment.  I had to try and trace him between these two.
Very well.  We will deal with the details later.  Did you do so?
And you sent the information back?
Did you continue with the project?
It is on record that Mr van Zyl ultimately received an order to execute a project regarding Gavin Evans.
Were you involved in the execution of that project in any way whatsoever?
As I've said, we will return to the details of that later.  Why were you not involved?  Why was it taken away from you?

Because I must have taken too long with it.  It wasn't that it wasn't important to me but I was caught up in the blue plan business and the establishment of these businesses, so I was more in Natal to establish Capall, than what I was here at that point.
Were you told what you were supposed to concentrate on when the Gavin Evans project was taken away from you?
What I had to concentrate on?
Yes what you were supposed to do.
I was involved with the blue plan.
Very well.  So were there any problems in the CCB with regard to the fact that you had to continue with the blue plan?
No, I assumed that they were happy that this was done.
You've already referred to the course that you did for a month.  Was it a full-time course?
And that was for the month of May?
So that brings us to the end of May 1989.
Which is five months on from January at that point.

After the completion of this course, which you did with the good blessings of the CCB along with their finance, what happened furthermore with regard to CCB activities?  Were you still involved with the blue plan?
And were there any other projects, so to speak, which came to your side, or any other instructions that you had to execute for the CCB?
Could you explain this to us?
I had to do a placement of a person in Namibia.
Do you have personal knowledge of the circumstances surrounding the recruitment of Mr Aitchison?
Did you regard Mr Aitchison as an aware or an unaware, or unconscious member?
From whom did you receive the order?
Very well.  If we examine the time schedule surrounding Aitchison's placement, can you recall more or less when it would have been?
Approximately June, July or August in 1989.
Just to view this in context, during these periods did you often travel abroad?
With reference to African countries, that is?
And in this period of June, July and August, during this time, did you visit any European countries?
Once again, the expansion of a company, to try to promote my blue plan, with a businessman, I went with a businessman to try to establish this.
Did you only go to Greece at that stage?
And so it was official business in promotion of the blue plan?
You stated that you also visited Namibia and that indeed you incorporated Lema as a company in Windhoek.
That is correct.  I could not do or practice the company as a singular unit, that is why I had to establish Lema B in Windhoek.
Can you recall precisely when this was?  We can use a general time period if you want.
It was approximately with my return from Greece.
So it would have been in July or August as well?
More or less the same time when Aitchison was placed?
Yes.  The company was registered before Aitchison was there.
So it was shortly before that?
Yes, because I had been there previously to purchase a company in Namibia.
It was just to look for a company to acquire in Namibia.  I knew what I was doing at that point, because I wanted to establish Lema there.
And did Lema in Namibia do any good business?
No, it didn't, it was registered, but it didn't.
Was this particular company incorporated with Aitchison in mind?
Did it not have anything to do with that?
It was still a bona fide expansion of the blue plan?
This trip to Greece and the examination of Europe, upon whose initiative was this done?

Once again, the question originates that originally you were told to examine KwaZulu Natal and the next thing you find yourself in the Greek Islands, which is a little far from KwaZulu Natal.  How did this happen?  Was this the long term vision regarding the activities?
At that stage I didn't know, now I know that there was.
Were you told to expand to Europe?
Mr Burger told me, and that is what I tried to do.
Very well and eventually you went to Germany as well?
When was your first time that you visited Germany, can you recall?
August, approximately, I cannot recall precisely, it was August 1989.
And was this once again an instruction?
To do a pre-study for a transfer to there.
So at that point it was the vision that you would ultimately settle in Europe?

Yes.  Mr Burger called me in and asked me how I would feel about settling permanently in Germany, about being stationed there and I was in favour of it.  They sent me to Germany to expand the blue plan of Lema once again, to give me movement room to contact German companies and that is what I did.  I placed advertisements in newspapers, made contact with business people, I examined the schooling systems and went to establish office space and to obtain housing.  I went to examine the scene for this.
And you did it in the end?
So at that stage the entire focus of your activities was actually from the internal side to the external side?
And during this same period of time that we have referred to, you received an instruction to handle Aitchison?
And did you indeed physically meet with Aitchison?
The first time was at a hotel in Norwood, thereafter in Swaziland and then again in Namibia.
Very well.  And was funding made available by the CCB for the establishment of Aitchison?

Mr Chairman, unfortunately I will have to deal with the whole Lubowski/Aitchison saga in view of the questions that have been put here to different witnesses, so although Mr Maree did not ask for amnesty in this regard, there's nothing in terms of my instructions he  had to ask for amnesty for.  I have to place this within the bigger picture, when we're dealing with Mr Gavin Evans, so at this stage I'm dealing with this.  Therefore you say that you went to establish Aitchison there?
And did you also meet him personally in Namibia?
And did you conduct the establishment there?

Sorry just before you proceed.  This word establishment, what did it entail to establish Aitchison?  Was that just to recruit him as an unaware member, or did you employ him at Lema, fix him up with a job, or what are you talking about when you say you had to establish Aitchison?

He was already recruited Sir, so I had to establish him in South West, in Namibia, by settling him in, getting him housing and seeing if I could get him a job and a motor vehicle and moving his family there.
Perhaps we could deal with this briefly.  So with regard to Aitchison, if we understand your evidence correctly, it was not a short term thing?
No, I was instructed to place Aitchison in Namibia and there was also a plan for him to be a so-called English sleeper because Namibia was on the verge of its reawakening at that stage.
If I recall correctly, the election took place approximately during August in 1989.
Was funding made available by the CCB as well?
And you said that he had to take his family there, did he have a family?
I don't know if it was his wife, I think he also had two children.
And the lady who was going with him?

Yes, so originally there was a problem, he would have had to wait a month because the school times for the children were not suitable and I had to get quotes for his family, the Defence Force wanted three quotes for the transportation of his furniture to Namibia.
So he was established in Namibia at that point, but his family was yet to follow?
And the arrangements for this were underway?
And he agreed to go and stay there?
And at that point, was there any particular instruction which Mr Aitchison had to execute there that you knew of?
Yes, he had to try and get a job, but I also told him that the job wasn't the most important, because we would be paying him a salary while he was there.
So he was already receiving funding?

Yes and there was also a problem with housing because in Windhoek there wasn't a lot of housing because UNTAG was in Windhoek at that stage, so all the housing was occupied, but he did find a garden cottage with somebody.
And that was also another reason why his wife and family couldn't join him, because the housing situation hadn't been sorted out yet.
And he did get a job.  Did you find the job for him, or did he find it himself?
No, he found it himself.  He was a journalist and a cartoon sketcher so he managed to get the job himself.
Did you have any instructions for him with regard to illegal activities that he had to execute there with regard to the political situation and the intimidation or murder of persons?
Did you yourself have such orders which you would ultimately have to send through to him?
If I understand you correctly, your instruction was merely to establish him there for later usage.
Yes.  I did not recruit him either, I was simply given a document and I was told to go and meet this man and to establish him in Namibia, that is all.
Very well.  We are now aware of the fact that at a certain point Adv Anton Lubowski was murdered in Namibia, the date being the 12th of September.
Where were you on the 12th of September?
Had you visited Namibia at any point during that time?
I was in and out of Namibia.  Four days before Mr Lubowski's death I was in Namibia.
Did you have anything whatsoever to do with the death of Lubowski?
Did you have any knowledge that it was going to happen?
We will deal with the following matter at a later point.  By nature of the situation it became known to you that Mr Aitchison was indeed arrested.

Now with regard to his recruitment by a certain Knox police officer who introduced him to Mr Barnard who was then handed over to Mr Botha and brought in to the CCB, did you have any knowledge of that background?
You said that you regarded him as an unconscious member.
It would appear from the evidence that he was conscious.
If this whole situation had been known to you, would you have placed your man there?
It was my order.  If I had known, in retrospect it is easier to say, but I think I might have acted differently.
It is clear that there was no particular cut-off date or point with Mr Aitchison.
Yes, from my side I followed it through as such.
